data.title: Weird behavior in Windows Server 2012 multi-user environment
data.body: When using Atom in a multi-user environment, like when remoting into Windows Server 2012, only one person can use Atom at a time. If I have Atom open first, and then some else from another session tries to open Atom their window opens on my session.

data.title: Thunderbolt issues after connect/disconnect from Mac
data.body:
Issue:
- Font/UI is blurry when atom is open onto a Thunderbolt screen
- Atom editor window truncated after reconnect to Thunderbolt screen

Steps to repeat:
1. Connect your Mac to a Thunderbolt display
2. Open Atom in your Thunderbolt display
3. Open a project to have files in your project manager and multiple files open
4. With Atom still open, disconnect your Thunderbolt display
5. Notice that on your Mac your Atom editor has all blurry fonts (If you close and re-open Atom, then all fonts are now clean/sharp again.)
6. Reconnect your Thunderbolt display and notice that your 'larger' Atom editor now has some odd white truncation until the window is resized.

data.title: Documentation: groupChangesSinceCheckpoint takes no parameters
data.body:
According to the documentation, `editor.groupChangesSinceCheckpoint` takes no parameters, but it does take one parameter: the checkpoint. 

This confused me.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.1.0/src/text-editor.coffee#L1149

data.title: How to deprecate commands?
data.body:
I am unable to find a way to deprecate existing command and introduce a new one.

This could've been worked around if we had a way to specify title for commands, but unfortunately, we don't have that, we just pass a string that atom converts to a title automatically. So we can not have a command `linter:togglePanel` with the text `Linter: Toggle Panel (depreciated)`.

Ref: https://github.com/atom-community/linter/pull/990

data.title: Revisit keymap#35 - international keyboard support.
data.body:
International Support in atom is somewhat lackluster. In reality it's not, but it sure feels that way. If you live anywhere outside the US, it means you usually don't have a US Keyboard layout. This is pretty much everyone.

There has been a lot of tickets on this topic, and they're all closed in favor of this one: https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/35 my personal impression is, that it's too easy to ignore when you're on an US keyboard yourself. This is, why i'm raising the issue here again, and not in the keymap project.

I would like to petition for one of two things, both of which are not _too_ hard to do. Both would make the experience for new atom users a lot better.

a) you could either make the popular (and apparently amazing) package `keyboard-localization` part of EVERY atom install automatically.

b) you could remove all Ctrl+Alt Shortcuts from the default shortcuts.

Either one will work around the issue.

The actual solution would be to correctly support the AtlGr Key, but this seems to be a problem upstream, and there's no telling when that can get resolved.

data.title: Gigantic and blurred fonts
data.body:
Under **Linux**, using new **Atom 1.2.0-beta1** (didn't try -beta0) with Atom Dark UI+Syntax styles, I experience very big font size on File Tree, status bar, file tabs. Editor's font can be adjusted under settings but the font size X appears much bigger (approximately 5pt) than the regular X size of other editors (and previous Atom's versions), and the font is blurred. The font is blurred also in status bar and file tabs, the only place where is not is on file tree explorer (but gigantic anyway). Even MiniMap preview is much larger and blurred.
My styles.less is empty, and Atom produces no errors on startup. Using Atom Material UI+Syntax styles, editor's font is not blurred, but other fonts around are still gigantic and blurred.

Building and installing back versions 1.1.0 or 1.1.0-beta1, solves the issue and everything is back to normal.

Perhaps a bug with new Electron's version?

data.title: Markdown preview strips leading spaces in code blocks
data.body:
When a code block is used, leading spaces in the first line are stripped:

![atom-md](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/625793/10967984/a8994892-83be-11e5-9937-e31543f44425.png)

This doesn't happen with other markdown implementations, e.g. here on GitHub:

```
  383 1
  607 3
23966 0
```

Claim diff in files (e.g. +99 / -99) and show yellow in tree-view even if no diff present
data.body:
Claim diff in files (e.g. "+99, -99" in status-bar) and show yellow in tree-view even if no diff present. 

No diff indication in editor itself for any of these files.
"+n, -n" in status-bar for all of these files.
Git status "clean".

See screenshot:

Windows10, Atom 1.1.0 (29.10.2015, 23:09:40)

Tried to remove and add the project folder. Did not help. 

Thanks for any suggestions. :-)

data.title: atom can't high-light C language code correctly.
data.body:
OS:Windows 10 64bit
Atom: 1.1.0
color style: default

I found atom can't high-light correctly in C code.
When a macro define with another macro, like this:
# define ABC XYZ(1)

struct MY_STRUCT {
/\* code */
};

The keyword "struct" is expected with colored, but the result is white without any color.
But the next keyword will be right. As follows:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6660768/10961009/f8b95c6c-83c4-11e5-8a34-e86b2bf3102a.png)

data.title: OS X File Icons
data.body:
I've created file icons in the ICNS format for use in on OS X, as well as updating the atom-Info.plist file's icon paths. These icons cover every file type that was listed in the Info.plist.

Edit: Here's a preview of some of the icons, as they appear full-size:

![Full Size Icons](http://i.imgur.com/sD03Hkj.png)

Here's how they appear in a list or in column view:

![32x32 and smaller](http://i.imgur.com/ycfCPBy.png)

Note that for other platforms, it is possible to easily convert these from ICNS to ICO or other formats by extracting the PNGs using [IConvert Icons](https://iconverticons.com/online/#).

For anyone wondering, [here's the PSD on Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/s/z521d6bby4izrgo/Fortran.psd?dl=0) for the Fortran 1024x1024 image. It can easily be used to add other file extensions/formats in future.

One other note: I followed the TextMate 2 icons' general style, preferring all-caps when possible, but switching to camelcase whenever it's a part of the language's name (e.g. BibTeX or OCaml).

TODO:

- [x] Fix markdown-preview specs

data.title: Allow synchronous control of scroll position through TextEditor model
data.body:
This PR adds the ability to manipulate a TextEditor's vertical scroll position at the model level, via a new method, `::setFirstVisibleScreenRow` method, which is marked as `Experimental` for the time being. It also un-deprecates `TextEditor::getFirstVisibleScreenRow`, making it possible to synchronously read the editor's vertical scroll position.

This was driven out by vim-mode's [`ScrollFullPage` commands](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/blob/e1d1a3edbaa16b6010e688b07c6cb3b9cd5c95a9/lib/motions/general-motions.coffee#L454), which need to synchronously update the editor's scroll position.

I've refactored the presenter so that it doesn't store its own copy of the `scrollRow` and `scrollColumn` state, using the model instead as the source of truth for these concepts. As part of this effort, I refactored the way the presenter's `scrollTop` and `scrollLeft` are initialized; they're now computed based on the `firstVisibleScreen{Row,Column}` as soon as the necessary measurements (line-height and base-character-width) are assigned.

Refs https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/pull/906

data.title: Add portable mode for Mac
data.body: Similar to portable mode for Windows and Linux, but the relative path for the portable .atom home directory has a deeper nesting.

data.title: file reformatting on open
data.body: I have files with a `.examples` extension that recently started to reformat on open. They look normal for a split second before many spaces and page breaks are added to the file. If I hit undo at this point I can get the file back into its normal format. I'm sure that this is probably a 3rd party package, but I have a lot of them. What is the preferred method of tracking down what is causing this?

data.title: atom/Whitespace package eat random characters on save !
data.body:
Step 1: atom --safe
Step 2: Open http://gundvang.dk/atom/fonts.js
Step 3: Save As `font2.js`
Step 4: Notice the missing `i`of `if` at line 22 and various missing character ( for example `$('.expanded')` at line 217 miss the `x`)
Step 5: Undo (file is ok)
Step 6: Disable package whitespace
Step 7: Save As `font3.js` (file is ok)
Step 8: Enable package whitespace
Step 9: Save As `font4.js`
Step 10: See the file mangled again (but in my case different mangle !)

[issue on discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/t/saving-js-and-scss-deletes-random-letters/20431/18)

![img1](https://i.gyazo.com/e676b79b43c92cf3944723ef40d7651f.png)

![img2](https://i.gyazo.com/888980d8af99ce4e75b07d47fd30c444.png)

data.title: Reopen closed tab should restore cursor position/undo history/etc...
data.body:
If I use "Reopen closed tab" it is because I accidentally closed a tab I was working on, that is why I expect Atom to restore 
- [ ] cursor position
- [ ] undo history
- [ ] folds
- [ ] more...?

data.title: [Windows] Atom installer depends on .Net
data.body: Atom installer depends on .Net. There are quite some other alternatives (may I suggest NullSoft?) that don't need/depend .Net, and given the fact that Atom itself doesn't depend on .Net in any way, maybe porting the installer to something else would be a good idea.

data.title: Caret position completely broken after updating to 1.1
data.body:
I'm on Ubuntu Linux, I just read the release blog post for 1.1 and then proceeded to update atom. The new caret positioning mechanism is completely broken for me, as demonstrated in the following screencast: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CPgFNo4OlHg
Sometimes hitting the left-arrow key even moves the caret to the right :-/

I tried updating to the beta version but that didn't help. I'll have to downgrade to an earlier version, if I find one!

data.title: Pressing Ctrl while the page is being inertially scrolled decreases the font size
data.body:
I think it maybe only reproducible on a Mac. I'm using two-finger scroll on MBP, which has this 'inertia' effect, causing the page to slowly decelerate scrolling after two fingers were already lifted from the touch pad surface. So if I press Ctrl during the inertia scrolling (after I physically stopped dragging fingers onto the touch pad surface), - the font becomes tiny as if I pressed Ctrl + <minus> multiple times.

I'm using Atom 1.1.0 on OSX 10.10.5.

data.title: Atom trying to upload something and blocked by network
data.body:
Atom version: 1.1.0
OS: Windows 7
Behaviour: Crashes when OS detects file upload.
Packages: default.

Just suddenly atom started crashing after copying files from Atom instance to another. It crashes not because I'm copying files but somehow my OS detects it sa a file upload and blocks the action immediately. If there's a usage data upload back to Atom how can we turn this off ? In blocked environments I'm not allowed to report usage neither do uploads.

Thanks.
![upload_not_permitted](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5233805/10937905/5ccddcd4-82dd-11e5-80f9-01d3e5017bb9.png)
![atom_crashing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5233805/10937906/5ce5a026-82dd-11e5-93bf-445820535192.png)

data.body: I have a large repo (7.5Gb) and atom crashes every time I attempt to open any file in the project. Could this be because of the large repo or because the index file is over 2mb ?
